• Iran’s nuclear program has been a point of contention with Western countries since 2006, due to suspicions regarding its intended purposes.
• The United Nations Security Council imposed sanctions targeting specific companies associated with Iran’s nuclear activities, thereby increasing Iran’s economic isolation.

• These UN sanctions notably restrict Iran’s nuclear, missile, and military exports, and also target investments in Iran’s oil, gas, and petrochemical sectors, exports of refined petroleum products, as well as financial and shipping activities involving the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, banks, and insurance companies.
• In 2012, the European Union intensified its sanctions against Iran by joining the longstanding US oil embargo, further restricting Iran’s economic activities.

• In 2015, Iran and the P5+1 countries (United States, United Kingdom, France, Russia, China, and Germany) reached a nuclear deal, which was expected to lead to the removal of the main sanctions by early 2016.
• Despite the easing of some sanctions, Iran faces ongoing difficulties in international trade, primarily because it cannot freely transact in US dollars.
• Iran’s substantial reserves of oil and gas suggest that, if parity with oil and gas prices is established, the Iranian rial could potentially become a global reserve currency.

• In 2018, the United States unilaterally withdrew from the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) and re-imposed sanctions targeting Iran’s oil exports, petrochemical industry, shipping sector, metals trading, and banking transactions.
• The Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) enables Iran to purchase new aircraft, easing some restrictions on its international trade capabilities.
• U.S. Undersecretary of State William J. Burns estimates that Iran may be losing up to $60 billion annually in energy investment due to sanctions.
• Sanctions have increased the cost of imports into Iran by an average of 24%.
• The latest round of sanctions could result in Iran losing approximately $50 billion annually in oil revenues.
• Iran has been increasingly resorting to barter trade as its access to the international dollar payment system has been denied, prompting a shift in its trade practices.
• Iranian officials view the large-scale withdrawal of international companies from Iran as an "opportunity" for domestic companies to fill the market gap.
• The International Energy Agency (IEA) reported that Iranian oil exports fell to a record low of 860,000 barrels per day (bpd) in September 2012, down from 2.2 million bpd at the end of 2011.
• The decline in oil exports led to reduced revenues and caused street protests in Tehran due to the collapse of the Iranian rial, Iran’s local currency.
• September 2012 marked Iran’s lowest oil output since 1988.
• The economic impact of sanctions has been severe, causing welfare losses across all income groups in Iran, with wealthier groups experiencing greater losses than poorer groups.
• Post-sanctions, there was a decline in income concentration and the share of top income groups within Iran’s economy.

• According to U.S. estimates, Iran could reduce the global crude oil price by 10%, which would save the United States approximately $76 billion annually based on the 2008 world oil price of $100 per barrel.
• The National Iranian American Council (NIAC) reports that sanctions have cost the United States over $175 billion in lost trade and resulted in 279,000 lost jobs.

• Between 2010 and 2012, sanctions caused EU member states to lose more than twice the trade revenue lost by the United States, with Germany losing between $23.1 billion and $73.0 billion, Italy between $13.6 billion and $42.8 billion, and France between $10.9 billion and $34.2 billion.
• Iran’s GDP growth turned negative in 2013, with a contraction of −5%.
• The unofficial unemployment rate in Iran reached 20% by mid-2012.
• Iran’s oil exports decreased from 2.5 million bpd in 2011 to 1.4 million bpd in 2014.
• By 2013, Iran had approximately $80 billion in foreign exchange reserves frozen overseas due to sanctions.
• Automobile production in Iran declined by 40% between 2011 and 2013.
• The U.S. government stated in 2015 that Iran’s economy had become "fundamentally incapable of recovery" without a nuclear agreement with the West.

• The tentative rapprochement between Iran and the U.S. starting in the second half of 2013 has the potential to significantly alter geopolitical dynamics and economic opportunities, potentially reducing Middle Eastern tensions and positioning Iran as a promising emerging market.

• In January 2019, President Hassan Rouhani blamed the U.S. for Iran’s declining economy following the U.S. withdrawal from the nuclear deal and re-imposition of sanctions, estimating damages between $150 billion and $200 billion.
• Following the August 2024 cyberattack, Iranian banks were targeted by IRLeaks, which Politico described as the "worst cyberattack" in Iranian history.
• The attack resulted in the compromise of approximately 20 out of 29 Iranian credit institutions, with the Iranian government reportedly paying millions of dollars in ransom to IRLeaks.
• The Iranian supreme leader attributed the cyberattack to Israel and the United States, without explicitly acknowledging the attack on the banking system.
• Politico suggested possible U.S. or Israeli involvement due to regional tensions and U.S. accusations of Iran interfering in the 2024 American elections.
• The hackers involved were likely freelance, motivated by monetary gain, with an Iranian firm paying at least $3 million to IRLeaks to halt the attack and recover data.
